instances.input: Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2: Dear Specialist, I am writing to request your assistance in the care of Mr XXXX, who has been diagnosed with sepsis of unspecified organism following a fall and subsequent aspiration pneumonia. Mr XXXX has a complicated medical history, including spinocerebellar disease and associated deafness, which have made it difficult to carry out a comprehensive assessment of his condition. In particular, his poor swallow has resulted in concerns about his nutritional status, and we are trying to arrange an IMCA to carry out a best interests meeting with regard to a potential NJT. However, we are uncertain whether this would be in Mr XXXX's best interests, given his malnourished and frail state. We would be grateful if you could provide us with your expert opinion regarding Mr XXXX's prognosis and any potential long-term implications of his diagnosis. This information will be valuable in helping us determine the best course of action for his care. Many thanks, Which of the following does this referral letter refer to? Please only output the option. Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear [Name],

I am writing to refer my patient, Mr XXXX, who was recently diagnosed with J69.0 - Pneumonitis due to inhalation of food and vomit. Mr XXXX was admitted to our hospital due to increasing shortness of breath over several months on a background of investigations for Parkinson's disease. He was diagnosed with recurrent aspirations and recovered well. However, he experienced a fall and injured his back while an inpatient. An XR lumbar spine showed a stable L1 anterior wedge fracture which was treated conservatively with analgesia and therapy.

Since his discharge, Mr XXXX has experienced increasing difficulty opening his bowels and passing urine. A post void bladder scan showed only 260ml. While he continued to mobilise normally, there were concerns regarding weakness. A PR exam showed reduced but intact sensation and normal tone but with reduced ability to squeeze. An MRI spine was requested on 8-5-18 and showed some retropulsion of bony fragments into the anterior one third of the spinal canal. However, CSF signal remained around the conus and surrounding nerve roots.

We would appreciate your expert input regarding the management of Mr XXXX's condition. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1: 

Dear [Name of Referring Physician],

I am referring a patient to you who was admitted after a fall with loss of consciousness, thought likely secondary to postural hypotension. The patient has a history of AF, CVA 2017, thalamassaemia trait, and portal hypertension. She normally lives fairly independently at home and has no package of care. However, she reports having two falls per day and was admitted due to a significant deterioration in her condition. 

On admission, inflammatory markers were raised, but these settled after treatment for aspiration pneumonia. The patient had a poor oral intake prior to admission, with associated weight loss on a background of low BMI previously. Her BMI is currently at 17. She was reviewed by speech and language therapy and found to have severe oropharyngeal dysphagia. As a result, she is advised for NBM and NG feed. The cause of her deterioration remains unclear, and fatigability was noted over the course of assessment. CT head and MRI for ?further CVE demonstrated no evidence of infarct or haemorrhage. Small vessel disease, including the pons, was noted. 

We are currently awaiting videofluoroscopy and AChR antibodies. We would be very grateful for your opinion as to whether her symptoms could all be explained by previous stroke with small vessel disease of the brainstem, or whether this might represent an alternative aetiology such as myasthenia or bulbar palsy. 

Thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1: 

Dear Infectious Diseases Specialist,

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient Name], who has been diagnosed with J18.9 - Pneumonia, unspecified organism. He was admitted with a seizure-fall and shortness of breath due to a background of epilepsy. He presented with fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea and is currently being treated for a chest infection with amoxicillin and clarithromycin. The patient is well-known to Dr. Page, Dr. Burn, and the Dorset epilepsy team. He is taking anti-epileptic medications such as epilim chrono, tegnetol retard, diazepam, phenobarbital, and has a vagal nerve stimulator implanted. 

Since he was moved to A4, he has had two episodes of reduced responsiveness, only responding to voice. Both episodes have resolved spontaneously and the impression is that these are seizures-postictal state. As his primary care physician, I would be grateful if you could assess and manage his condition. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1: 

To Whom It May Concern, 

I am referring Mr. XXXX to your clinic for further evaluation and management of his low back pain. Mr. XXXX is a 49-year-old gentleman who was admitted to our hospital with chronic low back pain after falling outside of his GP practice. He has a history of complex spinal problems and was ruled out for cauda equina by CT scan. 

Mr. XXXX was initially under orthopaedics who deemed it safe to discharge him. However, he experienced an unresponsive period where his sats dropped to 88% and he started twitching. Although he remembers nothing about the incident and had no pre-warning symptoms, he reports possible similar episodes in the past. 

Given this episode, we would be grateful for a neurology review to rule out any underlying neurological causes of his chronic low back pain. We appreciate your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Dear Dr. [Neurologist's name],

I am writing to refer my patient, Mr. [Patient's name], who has been diagnosed with R55 - Syncope and collaps. Mr. [Patient's name] is a 53-year-old gentleman who was recently admitted following a syncopal episode. He had a one week history of right-sided headache and experienced nausea and dizziness shortly before losing consciousness for 2-3 minutes while sitting in a chair. On regaining consciousness, he developed a right-sided tremor but had no focal weakness. During his previous admission, he had an MRI that showed abnormal signal in the left posterior frontal region and some small vessel ischemic change.

In view of the recurrence of his symptoms, we have requested another MRI, telemetry and an EEG. Given his complicated medical history and complex diagnostic presentation, we would appreciate your expert neurological opinion. Mr. [Patient's name] is due to see Dr. Page in neurology clinic in the next 6-52 weeks. We kindly request your assistance to ensure prompt and effective care for our patient.

Dear Dr Page,

I am writing to refer Mr XXXX, a 79-year-old man who was admitted to our hospital with a urinary tract infection. During his admission, Mr XXXX has experienced frequent unresponsive episodes, lasting up to a few minutes, which are not associated with posture, pallor or any other specific triggers. His wife reports that he did not have these episodes before admission and is concerned that his cognition has declined since admission.

Telemetry has found that Mr XXXX has AF and ventricular ectopics, and he has had fluctuating BP drops since admission. We feel that Mr XXXX would benefit from a consultation with you to help manage these symptoms and to help us determine the cause of his unresponsive episodes.

Thank you for your attention to Mr XXXX's case. We appreciate your assistance in his care.

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Dr. Specialist,

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient Name], an elderly male with a recent diagnosis of J18.9 - Pneumonia, unspecified organism. He presented to our hospital with sob, cough, and wheeze, for which he was placed on Amoxicillin. Additionally, a recent CT scan revealed liver lesions, and he has been awaiting gastroenterology review and repeat CT TAP.

On [Date], we received a PEWS call when he became unresponsive, with a GCS of 14 and confused. Dysarthria was also noted to be worse than normal. Sepsis was not identified as the cause of this confusion, and other potential causes have been ruled out. A CT head on [Date] revealed moderately extensive white matter ischemic changes, and several focal areas of low density. There are no indications of a large recent infarct, intracranial hemorrhage, or space-occupying lesion. However, there is moderate parenchymal involutional change.

Based on these findings, we believe that a new stroke may be causing his symptoms, and we would appreciate your input and advice on how best to manage this patient.

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1:

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer a 76-year-old male patient who was admitted to our hospital with a general feeling of malaise which was later diagnosed as a UTI. He has a medical history of Parkinson syndrome, COPD, Alzheimer's, OA and BPH. He also presented with possible aspiration pneumonia during his admission. Despite his prior diagnosis of Parkinson syndrome, he has not received input from PD services nor had further investigation. Currently, he is medically fit for discharge, however, he presents with rigidity, cogwheeling, bradykinesia, and intention tremor. We are also aware of his flat affect and the concerns regarding his safe swallow. We would highly appreciate your input and advice on whether this patient has PD and whether a trial of levodopa would be helpful.

Thank you for your time and expertise.

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1:

Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer a patient of mine, Mr. John Doe, for further investigation and management of his symptoms. He was admitted to our hospital on 1-9-15 following a tonic-clonic seizure which was thought to be secondary to a low magnesium after starting Omeprazole 40mg QDS. He did not remember the events and had no prodromal symptoms. He had no history of previous seizures. A CT Brain was performed which showed no change in the size of the left MCA aneurysm, apart from a slight increase in calcification. Magnesium was replaced IV and Omeprazole was changed to Ranitidine. He returned back to normal and was discharged. However, since his discharge, his family noticed him becoming increasingly confused with reports of visual hallucinations. He became more restless and aggressive, and was brought to the ED. On admission, he reported having visual hallucinations since discharge associated with a headache. There was no history of fever. He had no speech-visual disturbance, no focal weakness in extremities, no history of SOB-cough-night sweats, and no history abdominal pain, but was complaining of some dysuria. Throughout the day, he became increasingly confused and agitated. He absconded from the hospital, very unsteady and unsafe on feet, aggressive, and difficult to manage. He was seen by a passing paramedic who knew the patient and was able to calm him and bring him back to the hospital. He was reviewed by the psychiatric team who found him to be floridly psychotic with thought disorders, disorientation in time, place, and person, as well as paranoia (believing staff wanted to harm him). He also appeared to be experiencing auditory and visual hallucinations. He clearly lacked capacity and became increasingly aggressive. He was given IM Haloperidol 2.5mg initially, but this had little effect so at MET call was put out. On arrival, he was needing a lot of encouragement and restraint to keep him in his room, and was grabbing and his head and rolling around. He was therefore given 5mg IV of Haloperidol, and his friend was then able to calm him somewhat. He was then brought up to ITU where he was intubated and ventilated to allow for a repeat CT Brain and Lumbar puncture for possible encephalitis. 

We would be grateful for your advice on further investigations and management of this patient. Please contact me if you require further information.

Thank you for your assistance.

Kind regards,

Dear [Consultant Name],

I am writing to refer Mr. [Patient Name], who has been diagnosed with R41.0 - Disorientation, unspecified. He was admitted to Ansty on 1-9-15 following a tonic-clonic seizure, which was thought to be secondary to a low magnesium after starting Omeprazole 40mg QDS. He also appeared to be experiencing auditory and visual hallucinations. He clearly lacked capacity, and became increasingly aggressive. Mr. [Patient Name] was given IM haloperidol 2.5mg initially, but this had little effect, so a MET Call was put out. On arrival, he was needing a lot of encouragement and restraint to keep him in his room, and was grabbing his head and rolling around. He was then given 5mg IV of haloperidol, and his friend was able to calm him somewhat.

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 2:

Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer one of my patients, Mrs. Jane Shaw, for a neurological evaluation, as she has been experiencing unusual symptoms that we feel are not consistent with normal psychiatric presentations. Mrs. Shaw is an 88-year-old lady who has been experiencing strange episodes that could be associated with a migrainous or epileptiform aetiology, as well as more recent periods of severe agitation, rambling speech, and aggression, for which she has no memory.

Mrs. Shaw's episodes are unusual, as she can apparently present as her usual self, but then very suddenly there is a change, involving agitation, distress, and aggression. At times, she has appeared suicidal. Her speech during these episodes is rambling and apparently nonsensical. It has tended to last for around two hours, and on occasions, she has needed to be restrained whilst this is going on. These episodes always end with her developing a “blinding headache” and then feeling very drowsy. She has also developed psychotic symptoms, with delusions that her family and other people are attempting to kill her. It was unclear whether she developed these thoughts during the period of altered awareness or not. Once it resolves, she has no recollection of what has happened.

Over a few months, she has been developing strange episodes that may have a migrainous aetiology. She tends to feel something coming on, and it is unpleasant. She develops photophobia, needs the curtains to be drawn, and experiences visual changes, seeing zig-zag lines. She described this as if it is all around her and seen with both eyes. The episodes have tended to last for about 20 minutes and then quite swiftly “lift.” In between times, she has felt fine. These episodes have been coming on with increasing frequency. She was having them on a daily basis, and then in the lead-up to her admission, they started happening several times per day. They are not associated with a headache.

Mrs. Shaw has no past history of mental health problems. There is no family history of psychiatric illness or dementia.

The psychiatry liaison doctor who reviewed Mrs. Shaw feels that it is more likely that she is suffering from a neurological condition rather than a psychiatric one. It is possible that the brief events she has experienced prior to admission had a migrainous aetiology, though this could also have been epileptiform. The more recent episodes of severe agitation, rambling speech, and aggression (for which she has no memory) always end with a severe headache followed by drowsiness, which could be partial seizure activity. Post-ictal confusion might account for the development of delusional beliefs and associated distress. The focus on three words may be linked to this as well. Either way, he thinks that this requires further investigation.

We would be grateful if you could review Mrs. Shaw for a possible neurological cause for her symptoms and advise on further investigations and management of this patient. Please contact me if you require further information.

Thank you for your assistance.

Kind regards,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear neurologist,

I am writing to refer a 56 year old man who was initially admitted with a posterior circulation stroke, and has now developed further small infarcts bilaterally in the cerebrum. He was investigated and treated for possible temporal arteritis in Great Yarmouth, but biopsy was negative. Despite weaning down his own prednisolone and stopping it, his visual symptoms and headache have returned. The ophthalmologists in Bournemouth have considered TA again and restarted prednisolone at 80mg, but we are concerned that the whole picture of the strokes and visual symptoms might be related to a vasculitis.

He has also been seen by the rheumatology team who are continuing to treat as a possible TA, but we would appreciate your opinion on whether this could be related to an intracerebral vasculitis. He also has a dilative cardiomyopathy, which we thought could be leading to thromboembolic disease, but echo and carotid dopplers are not suggestive of this.

We would be very grateful for your thoughts and inputs into this case, and we look forward to hearing from you soon.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Kind regards,

This letter is to refer a 55-year-old female patient who has been experiencing left leg pain and weakness, numbness and weakness in the left arm, and loss of vision in the left eye. Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Neurology Team,

I am writing to refer a patient who was recently diagnosed with the disease I63.9 – Cerebral infarction, unspecified. The patient, A-W, collapsed suddenly and presented with symptoms of dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and left-sided neck pain. Upon examination, they were found to have right-sided nystagmus, right-sided droop, and retina not able to be clearly viewed on fundoscopy. She has been started on phenytoin and acyclovir, and her imaging, EEG, and bloods were unremarkable.

Dear Infectious Diseases Specialist,

I am writing to seek your advice regarding a patient who was recently admitted to our hospital with a suspected case of sepsis. The patient, a 76-year-old gentleman, was initially admitted on 14-04-18 with the onset of right-sided neck pain, which progressed to whole neck pain and eventually severe pain at the base of the skull, "like it's going to explode." No bacterial growth on Gram stain. We have sent the SCF for viral screening.

The patient was subsequently treated with antibiotics for sepsis of unknown origin, although viral meningitis has not been excluded as of yet. With his raised CSF protein, we are questioning if this could be explained by the traumatic nature of the LP, or if further investigations are warranted.

I would be grateful if you could advise further on the patient's condition and whether further investigations are required.

Thank you for your assistance in this matter.

Sincerely,
